### Feed Algorithm

> â€œDo you think your feed reflects **your choices** â€” or **the platformâ€™s choices about you?**â€

### ðŸ§  Feed Algorithm Interpretation Using Card Mechanics

To illustrate how platforms differ in *engagement efficiency*, we treat each minute of screen time like **drawing a card**:

- **Rank (2â€“10, J, Q, K, A)** â†’ how strong your engagement signal was  
- **Suit (platform personality)** â†’ how that platform *interprets and amplifies* that engagement

Youâ€™ll see that **not all platforms reward the same behavior equally** â€” some love viral spikes, some love steady engagement.

  

#### ðŸŽ­ Platform Algorithm Personalities â€” Rank Bias Model

Each platform doesn't just apply a fixed multiplier â€” it **biases specific rank categories** (Face, Ace, Mid, etc.).  
This models how **TikTok boosts viral spikes**, **Reddit rewards slower thread engagement**, and **YouTube locks users into deep watch sessions**.

| Platform | Algorithm Personality | Rank Preference Pattern |
|:--|:--|:--|
| **TikTok** | â™  Strategic viral retention â€” aggressively hunts viral spikes | **Face â†’ Ace â†’ 10** (very spike-oriented, punishes low/no engagement) |
| **Instagram / Threads** | â™¦ Aesthetic/status curation â€” polished trend amplification | **10 â†’ Face â†’ Mid** (reward polished content, suppress low-value scroll) |
| **YouTube** | â™  Strategic deep retention â€” optimizes long session depth | **Ace â†’ 10 â†’ Mid** (not chaotic, but strong on intentional consumption) |
| **Reddit / Discord** | â™£ Community depth â€” favors threads, steady engagement over spikes | **Mid â†’ Ace â†’ 10**, downweights Face spikes (less about virality) |
| **Snapchat** | â™¥ Emotional burst algorithm â€” high volatility, short attention loops | **Face spikes allowed, but low ranks common** (chaotic scroll-emotion mix) |
| **X/Twitter** | â™£ Fast discourse loop â€” rewards mid-level interaction & repost energy | **Mid + Face modest bias**, suppresses dead scrolling |
| **Facebook** | â™¦ Legacy ranking â€” mild engagement shaping, mostly neutral | **Slight mid bias**, nearly flat weighting otherwise |
| **None** | Neutral baseline â€” no algorithm shaping | All **rank_adj = 1.00** (control group) |


#### ðŸŽ® Rank Interpretation (Base Weights Before Platform Influence)

| Rank Category | Base Weight | Meaning in Attention Model |
|------------------------|:------------------------:|----------------------------|
| **Joker (0)** | **1.00** | Passive drift â€” counted time, no engagement signal |
| **2â€“4 (Low ranks)** | **1.00** | Glance-scroll, content seen without response |
| **5â€“9 (Mid ranks)** | **1.05** | Light scrolling or minor interaction â€” retention signal |
| **10** | **1.10** | High interest moment â€” actively watching or reading |
| **Ace (A)** | **1.25** | Intentional engagement â€” searching, saving, deep dwell |
| **Face Cards (J/Q/K)** | **1.50** | Emotional/viral spike â€” strong reaction triggers |


> ðŸš© **Raw minutes = counting cards without considering rank or suit.**  
> ðŸŽ¯ **Algorithm-adjusted attention = calculating your *true score* based on both rank (quality of engagement) and suit (type of platform algorithm).**

In other words:

- A 20-minute session on **Instagram Reels (â™¦ Ace)** scores **high adjusted attention**.
- A 40-minute **YouTube autoplay binge (â™  Joker)** has **high raw minutes but almost no algorithm-weighted value**.

- Two users can spend the **same time**, but **their card draws (attention efficiency) differ by platform**.
  - **TikTok may reward spike engagement**, while **Reddit rewards steady browsing**.
  - **YouTube may ignore your first 10 minutes**, but heavily weight the moment you **intentionally engage**.

### âœ… Key Takeaway

> **Algorithms donâ€™t just count your time â€” they interpret and score it.**  
> Some platforms are **time sinks**, while others are **attention amplifiers** â€” even if the minutes look the same.
